description: From Middle English wit, from Old English witt (‚Äúunderstanding, intellect, sense, knowledge, consciousness, conscience‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *witi, from Proto-Germanic *witjƒÖ (‚Äúknowledge, reason‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (‚Äúsee, know‚Äù).

Cognate with Dutch weet, German Witz, Danish vid, Swedish vett, Norwegian Bokm√•l vett, Gothic êåøêåΩêçÖêåπêçÑêåπ (unwiti, ‚Äúignorance‚Äù), Latin vide≈ç (‚Äúsee‚Äù), Bulgarian –≤–∏ÃÅ–¥—è (v√≠dja), Russian –≤–∏ÃÅ–¥–µ—Ç—å (v√≠det π), Sanskrit ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (vidyƒÅ). Compare wise.

examples: He's gone completely out of his wits.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, usually in the plural) The senses.
Intellectual ability; faculty of thinking, reasoning.
examples: Where she has gone to is beyond the wit of man to say.

entries.meaning: The ability to think quickly; mental cleverness, especially under short time constraints.
examples: My father had a quick wit and a steady hand.
The opportunity was right in front of you, and you didn't even have the wit to take it!

entries.meaning: Humour, especially when clever or quick.
examples: The best man's speech was hilarious, full of wit and charm.

entries.meaning: A person who tells funny anecdotes or jokes; someone witty.
examples: Your friend is quite a wit, isn't he?

description: From Middle English witen, from Old English witan, from Proto-West Germanic *witan, from Proto-Germanic *witanƒÖ, from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (‚Äúsee, know‚Äù).
Cognate with Icelandic vita, Dutch weten, German wissen, Swedish veta, and Latin vide≈ç (‚ÄúI see‚Äù). Compare guide.

verbs.description: wit (see below for this verb‚Äôs conjugation)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, chiefly archaic) Know, be aware of (constructed with of when used intransitively).
examples: You committed terrible actions ‚Äî to wit, murder and theft ‚Äî and should be punished accordingly.
They are meddling in matters that men should not wit of.
